docs.lead_paragraph: The history of American art at the end of the 20th century is at least in part the history of AIDS. Many artists died of the disease. Its presence shaped the image of the human body as a potent and volatile cultural emblem. Art played an aggressive role in battering away at the politics of denial that surrounded the epidemic. Despite all this, AIDS went all but unmentioned in the recent rash of retrospectives. One reason is simply that, with the successful use of expensive palliative drugs since the late 1990's, the disease has lost its aura of emergency for middle-class whites in the United States.
docs.abstract: Holland Cotter reviews art show Bodies of Resistance at Real Art Ways in Hartford; photo; show was organized by Visual AIDS (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the years, researchers have found hundreds of drugs to slow the growth of cancer. But they have found virtually nothing that can prevent cancers from forming. The goal is not just a drug to stop cancerous cells from growing. It must also be safe enough to be taken for years by healthy people, most of whom will never get cancer.

headline.main: Serendipity And Hope In War On Cancer

docs.abstract: Scientists at National Cancer Institute say they have promising candidate for drug that can prevent cancers from forming; drug is an aspirin-like drug, known as a selective cox-2 inhibitor, which is commmonly used to treat arthritis pain; by accident, scientists find that such drugs might also prevent cancer; photo of Dr William R Waddell (M)
